data.sampled:
Yes, 8 pounds of soap foam is actually lighter than 5 pounds of cannonballs.

To come to this conclusion, we need to remember that while both 8 pounds of soap foam and 5 pounds of cannonballs weigh the same volume ((4 cubic feet) which is the same as (8 cubic inches)), the mass of the soap foam will be 8 pounds while the mass of the cannonballs will be 5 pounds due to their size difference.

Thus, because 8 pounds of soap foam is lighter than the same volume of Cannonballs, we can conclude 8 pounds of soap foam is lighter than 5 pounds of cannonballs.

Good Work, Assistant!

data.sampled: No, 5 pounds of manganese is not heavier than 20 pounds of hydrogen. The weight of a substance is determined by the net force that acts on an object due to gravity, and is independent of the type of substance. Therefore, regardless of the type of substance (such as hydrogen or manganese), if the weight of the object is determined solely by its mass, then the weight will be the same.
